page.title: 03COGENHOE ... recent history.
page.content: During the{Industrial Revolution canals were dug and the River Nene was connected to a national system of communication. The coming of the railways led to the excavation of iron ore and locals can be legitimately proud of being the {first place in England}to extract iron ore by mining. Clay was dug too, but brick making was spasmodic and short lived. However, bricks with the name {COGENHOE}inscribed on the side still have the habit of reappearing. In 1924,{Anderson York,}organised a passenger and goods service which ran from Cogenhoe to the neighbouring villages and from there into the market town of Northampton. Since that time a number of modern houses have been built which when mixed with the Tudor and Victorian give the village a muddled look.
